Award.AwardTitle: Conference Participation Support Proposal - 19th Annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates; Vancouver, BC; October 12 - 15, 2016
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide funds to partially support the 19th annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates (CEU), which is held as part of the Fall Meeting of the APS Division of Nuclear Physics. This year's meeting will be held October 12 - 15, 2016, in Vancouver, BC. The CEU is a natural venue for students who have had an undergraduate research experience to present the results of their work and interact with other students as well as faculty and senior researchers. The CEU has been immensely successful in fostering this interaction, which helps students to have a broad introduction and exposure to research across nuclear physics, and to enable senior researchers to get to know some of the junior future leaders. Partial support will be provided for approximately 32 undergraduate students, out of a planned total of 150.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded approximately 32 undergraduate students to participate in the fall meeting of the Division of Nuclear Physics (DNP) as part of the 19th annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates (CEU) program in Vancouver, BC. During the meeting they met with professional physicists and one another, receive broad exposure to the quality and variety of cutting edge research conducted in the US and abroad, and observed how scientific results are disseminated at a professional meeting through formal presentations and informal conversation.

There were 165 students in attendance. Of these, 28% of the participants were women. In addition, out of the 129 self identified students, 10% were Hispanic, 1% Pacific Islander, 4% black, and 1% American Indian or Alaskan Native (categories defined by the NSF).  Underrepresented minorities are especially encouraged to present their work at the conference which provides them with more advanced opportunities and helps propagate a more diverse workforce,  which is a benefit to nuclear science, academia, and science as a whole.

This program has been successful in encouraging students to further their education in physics. The post conference survey (N=72) found a 10% increase of students interested in a PhD program in physics. In addition, all students would recommend this program to others.
